hints.title: Alive and Dead Sets
hints.content:
202: :label: def-alive-dead-sets

204: For any swarm state $\mathcal{S} = ((x_1, s_1), \dots, (x_N, s_N)) \in \Sigma_N$:
205: 
206: 1.  The **alive set**, $\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S})$, is the set of indices of all walkers with a survival status of 1.

214:

217: \mathcal{D}(\mathcal{S}) := \{i \in \{1, \dots, N\} \mid s_i = 0\}

hints.label: def-valid-state-space
hints.title: Valid State Space
hints.content:
259: :label: def-valid-state-space
260: 
261: A **Valid State Space** is a tuple $(\mathcal{X}, d_{\mathcal{X}}, \mu_{\mathcal{X}})$ with the following properties:
262: 
263: 1.  **Topological Structure:** The space $(\mathcal{X}, d_{\mathcal{X}})$ must be a **Polish space** (a complete, separable metric space). This ensures that notions of convergence and probability measures are well-defined.
264: 
265: 2.  **Measure Structure:** The space must be equipped with a **reference measure** $\mu_{\mathcal{X}}$ (e.g., Lebesgue measure for Euclidean spaces, or the Riemannian volume measure for manifolds). This measure is used to define probability densities for the noise kernels.
266: 
267: 3.  **Existence of Valid Noise:** The space must support a **Valid Noise Measure** ($\mathcal{P}_\sigma$ and $\mathcal{Q}_\delta$) as per {prf:ref}`def-valid-noise-measure`. This is the most critical functional requirement, as it implies the space has enough geometric regularity to satisfy:
268:     *   The **Axiom of Bounded Second Moment of Perturbation** ([](#def-axiom-bounded-second-moment-perturbation)).
269:     *   The **Axiom of Boundary Regularity** ([](#axiom-boundary-regularity)).
270: 
271: 4.  **Regularity of the Domain:** The **Valid Domain** $\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}} \subset \mathcal{X}$ must have a boundary $\partial \mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$ that is a null set with respect to any admissible noise measure. For example, if $\mathcal{X}$ is a smooth manifold, requiring a $C^1$ boundary is sufficient.
hints.section: ## 2. Global Conventions: Foundational Objects and Core Algorithmic Parameters

256: For the analytical framework to be sound, the State Space $(\mathcal{X}, d_{\mathcal{X}}, \mu_{\mathcal{X}})$ in which walkers evolve must satisfy a set of foundational properties. Any space that meets these criteria is considered a **Valid State Space**.
257: 
258: :::{prf:definition} Valid State Space
259: :label: def-valid-state-space
260: 
261: A **Valid State Space** is a tuple $(\mathcal{X}, d_{\mathcal{X}}, \mu_{\mathcal{X}})$ with the following properties:
262: 
263: 1.  **Topological Structure:** The space $(\mathcal{X}, d_{\mathcal{X}})$ must be a **Polish space** (a complete, separable metric space). This ensures that notions of convergence and probability measures are well-defined.
264: 
265: 2.  **Measure Structure:** The space must be equipped with a **reference measure** $\mu_{\mathcal{X}}$ (e.g., Lebesgue measure for Euclidean spaces, or the Riemannian volume measure for manifolds). This measure is used to define probability densities for the noise kernels.
266: 
267: 3.  **Existence of Valid Noise:** The space must support a **Valid Noise Measure** ($\mathcal{P}_\sigma$ and $\mathcal{Q}_\delta$) as per {prf:ref}`def-valid-noise-measure`. This is the most critical functional requirement, as it implies the space has enough geometric regularity to satisfy:
268:     *   The **Axiom of Bounded Second Moment of Perturbation** ([](#def-axiom-bounded-second-moment-perturbation)).
269:     *   The **Axiom of Boundary Regularity** ([](#axiom-boundary-regularity)).
270: 
271: 4.  **Regularity of the Domain:** The **Valid Domain** $\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}} \subset \mathcal{X}$ must have a boundary $\partial \mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$ that is a null set with respect to any admissible noise measure. For example, if $\mathcal{X}$ is a smooth manifold, requiring a $C^1$ boundary is sufficient.

hints.label: def-ambient-euclidean
hints.title: Ambient Euclidean Structure and Reference Measures
hints.content:
317: :label: def-ambient-euclidean
318: 
319: - The spaces $\mathcal{X} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ and $\mathcal{Y} \subset \mathbb{R}^m$ are finite-dimensional Euclidean domains with Lebesgue reference measures $\lambda_d$ and $\lambda_m$.
320: - All linear-algebraic objects (means, variances, covariances) and kernel densities are defined with respect to these Euclidean structures and Lebesgue measures. In particular, KDE normalizations use the standard Euclidean constants (e.g., $\int \exp(-\|y\|_2^2/(2\sigma^2))\,dy = (2\pi\sigma^2)^{m/2}$).
321: - The ambient dimensions $d$ and $m$ are fixed throughout.
hints.section: ## 2. Global Conventions: Foundational Objects and Core Algorithmic Parameters
hints.raw_directive:
314:     These structures, formally defined in subsequent sections, give rise to a set of fixed **environmental constants**, including the reward bound ($R_{\max}$), reward Lipschitz constant ($L_R$), the diameter of the projected valid domain ($D_{\mathrm{valid}} := \operatorname{diam}_{d_{\mathcal{Y}}}(\varphi(\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}))$), the diameter of the entire algorithmic space ($D_{\mathcal{Y}} := \operatorname{diam}_{d_{\mathcal{Y}}}(\mathcal{Y})$), and the **Projection Map Lipschitz Constant ($L_{\varphi}$)**.
315: 
316: :::{prf:assumption} Ambient Euclidean Structure and Reference Measures
317: :label: def-ambient-euclidean
318: 
319: - The spaces $\mathcal{X} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ and $\mathcal{Y} \subset \mathbb{R}^m$ are finite-dimensional Euclidean domains with Lebesgue reference measures $\lambda_d$ and $\lambda_m$.
320: - All linear-algebraic objects (means, variances, covariances) and kernel densities are defined with respect to these Euclidean structures and Lebesgue measures. In particular, KDE normalizations use the standard Euclidean constants (e.g., $\int \exp(-\|y\|_2^2/(2\sigma^2))\,dy = (2\pi\sigma^2)^{m/2}$).
321: - The ambient dimensions $d$ and $m$ are fixed throughout.

hints.label: def-reference-measures
hints.title: Reference Noise and Kernel Families
hints.content:
327: :label: def-reference-measures
328: 
329: - **Perturbation kernels on $\mathcal{X}$ (dimension $d$):**
330:   - Gaussian: $\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2 I_d)$ so that $\mathbb{E}[\|\xi\|_2^2] = d\,\sigma^2$.
331:   - Uniform ball: $\xi$ uniform on $B_d(0,\sigma)$ with density $1/\lambda_d(B_d(0,\sigma))$.
332: - **Cloning kernels on $\mathcal{X}$:** analogously parameterized by $\delta>0$ (e.g., $\mathcal{N}(0, \delta^2 I_d)$ or uniform on $B_d(0,\delta)$).
333: - **Smoothing kernels on $\mathcal{Y}$ (dimension $m$):**

329: - **Perturbation kernels on $\mathcal{X}$ (dimension $d$):**
330:   - Gaussian: $\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2 I_d)$ so that $\mathbb{E}[\|\xi\|_2^2] = d\,\sigma^2$.
331:   - Uniform ball: $\xi$ uniform on $B_d(0,\sigma)$ with density $1/\lambda_d(B_d(0,\sigma))$.
332: - **Cloning kernels on $\mathcal{X}$:** analogously parameterized by $\delta>0$ (e.g., $\mathcal{N}(0, \delta^2 I_d)$ or uniform on $B_d(0,\delta)$).
333: - **Smoothing kernels on $\mathcal{Y}$ (dimension $m$):**
334:   - Gaussian: $K_\sigma(y) = (2\pi\sigma^2)^{-m/2} \exp(-\|y\|_2^2/(2\sigma^2))$.

hints.label: def-n-particle-displacement-metric
hints.title: N-Particle Displacement Pseudometric ($d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}$)
hints.content:
419: :label: def-n-particle-displacement-metric
420: 
421: For any two swarms, $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$, define the (pseudo)metric by
422: 
423: $$
424: d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2)
425: := \Bigg( \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N d_{\mathcal{Y}}\!\big(\varphi(x_{1,i}), \varphi(x_{2,i})\big)^2
426: \;+
427: \; \frac{\lambda_{\mathrm{status}}}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N (s_{1,i} - s_{2,i})^2 \Bigg)^{\!1/2}.
428: $$
429: 
430: For algebraic convenience we will frequently write and bound its square,
431: 
432: $$
433: d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2)^2
434: = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_{1,i}), \varphi(x_{2,i}))^2 + \frac{\lambda_{\mathrm{status}}}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N (s_{1,i} - s_{2,i})^2.
435: $$
436: 
437: :::{admonition} Breaking Down the Formula
438: :class: note
439: :open:
440: This formula has two parts:
441: 
442: 1. **Position Changes** (first term): For each walker $i$, measure how far it moved in the algorithmic space, square it, then average over all walkers.
443: 
444: 2. **Status Changes** (second term): For each walker $i$, check if its status changed (alive ↔ dead). Since status is 0 or 1, $(s_{1,i} - s_{2,i})^2$ equals 1 if status changed, 0 if unchanged. Sum these up and weight by $\lambda_{\text{status}}$.

hints.label: def-metric-quotient
hints.title: Metric quotient of $(\Sigma_N, d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}})$
hints.content:
451: :::{prf:definition} Metric quotient of $(\Sigma_N, d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}})$
452: :label: def-metric-quotient
453: Define the equivalence relation $\mathcal{S}_1\sim\mathcal{S}_2$ iff $d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2)=0$. The **metric identification** (Kolmogorov quotient) is $\overline{\Sigma}_N := \Sigma_N/\!\sim$ with metric
454: 
455: $$
456: \overline d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}\big([\mathcal{S}_1],[\mathcal{S}_2]\big):= d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2),
457: $$

hints.label: proof-lem-borel-image-of-the-projected-swarm-space
hints.section: ## 2. Global Conventions: Foundational Objects and Core Algorithmic Parameters
hints.raw_directive:
475: :::
476: 
477: :::{prf:proof}
478: :label: proof-lem-borel-image-of-the-projected-swarm-space
479: Write $\mathcal X=\bigcup_m K_m$ with $K_m$ compact. Then $\varphi(\mathcal X)=\bigcup_m \varphi(K_m)$ is $F_\sigma$, hence Borel. Products and intersections with Borel sets are Borel; the status constraints are Borel in $\{0,1\}^N$. Hence the claim.

hints.label: def-displacement-components
hints.title: Components of Swarm Displacement
hints.content:
512: :label: def-displacement-components
513: 
514: For any two swarms, $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$, their total displacement is decomposed into two fundamental components:
515: 
516: 1.  **The Squared Positional Displacement ($\Delta_{\text{pos}}^2$):** The sum of squared distances between corresponding walkers in the algorithmic space.
517: 
518: $$
519: \Delta_{\text{pos}}^2(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2) := \sum_{i=1}^N d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_{1,i}), \varphi(x_{2,i}))^2
520: $$
521:
